ground_truth: She slides the paper sack toward him, and he looks inside to find the bottom full of fat, crawling earthworms. Marge's prowler is parked in an otherwise empty lot, and she sits talking with two young women at one end of an elevated dance platform in the deserted club not yet open for business. With one last bang, we cut to an extreme close-up of an insect lugging a worm, and a pull back from the screen reveals that we are in Marge's house, where Marge and Norm are watching television in bed. After a long beat, with silence except for the TV, Marge murmurs while still looking at the set. Marge gropes in the dark, and he sits in and picks up his phone, while Jerry sits dumbly and angrily snatches it up, then goes back to his food. Gary hands her a flimsy, and Marge takes it with one hand and looks, her other hand frozen with a forkful of food. Norm, who has been eating steadily throughout, looks over at Marge with mild interest, stares for a beat as he finishes chewing, then swallows and speaks. Jerry, Wade, and Stan Grossman sit around the kitchen table, harshly toplit by a hanging fixture, with the remains of coffee and a cinnamon filbert ring present on the table. Marge is at the reception desk while the clerk types into a computer console, and she is on a public phone. The brown Ciera enters and drives lazy S-curves around the few snow-covered cars parked on the roof of the lot, stops by one car, and Carl emerges, quickly scans the lot, then kneels in the snow at the back of the parked car and starts unscrewing its license plate. Carl pulls up and hands the attendant his ticket, and the attendant frowns uncomprehendingly at the ticket, still puzzled, saying nothing as Carl glances back and starts digging for money, peeling off one dollar bills. Bewildered, he looks about, then asks a mechanic passing by, his voice raised over the din of the shop, and the mechanic points while Jerry looks, stares, and swallows. Marge and Shep face each other at the other end of the floor in a grimy and cluttered glassed-in cubicle, silently talk, while Shep says nothing and stares at her. Jerry is worriedly pacing behind his desk when Marge has stuck in the door, then Marge plops into the chair opposite him, and Jerry stares at her, his mouth open. As Marge rises, Jerry looks blankly down at the papers on the desk in front of him. Marge enters and looks around the bar, a rather characterless, lowlit meeting place for business people, and it is a bald, paunching man of about Marge's age, rising from a booth halfway back.

Marge searches in the dark, and he sits in and picks up his phone, while Jerry sits dumbly and angrily grabs it up, then returns to his food. Gary hands her a flimsy, and Marge accepts it with one hand and looks, her other hand frozen with a forkful of food. Carl pulls up and hands the attendant his ticket, and the attendant frowns in confusion at the ticket, still puzzled, saying nothing as Carl glances back and starts searching for money, peeling off one-dollar bills. Bewildered, he gazes about, then inquires of a mechanic passing by, his voice raised over the noise of the shop, and the mechanic points while Jerry looks, stares, and swallows. Marge and Shep face each other at the opposite end of the floor in a grimy and cluttered glassed-in cubicle, silently communicate, while Shep says nothing and stares at her. As Marge rises, Jerry looks blankly down at the papers on the desk in front of him. Marge enters and gazes around the bar, a somewhat characterless, dimly lit meeting place for business people, and it is a bald, paunchy man of about Marge's age, rising from a booth halfway back.

A loud bang cuts to an insect lugging a worm on TV while Marge and Norm watch in bed. Marge murmurs, gropes for something; Jerry angrily grabs his phone. Marge enters, sees a bald man her age rising from a booth in a characterless bar.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: She effortlessly slides the paper sack across the table toward him, and without hesitation, he peers inside to discover that the bottom is brimming with fat, wriggling earthworms. Meanwhile, Marge's car is parked conspicuously in an otherwise barren lot, where she is seen conversing with two youthful women at one end of an elevated dance platform in the deserted club, which is not yet ready to welcome patrons for business. With a final, resounding bang, the scene transitions to an extreme close-up of an insect diligently dragging a worm, and as the camera pulls back from the screen, it becomes apparent that we are within the cozy confines of Marge's home. Here, Marge and Norm find themselves watching television together in bed. After a prolonged moment of silence, interrupted only by the faint sounds from the TV, Marge murmurs softly while keeping her eyes fixed on the screen. In the darkness, Marge tentatively gropes around, and he takes a seat, retrieving his phone. Jerry, meanwhile, sits in a state of bewilderment, angrily snatches up the phone, and then turns his attention back to his meal. Gary hands Marge a flimsy document, which she accepts with one hand, examining it intently while her other hand remains suspended with a forkful of food. Norm, who has been steadily focused on his meal, glances over at Marge with mild curiosity, pausing to observe her as he finishes chewing, subsequently swallowing before he finally speaks. Seated around the kitchen table under the harsh glare of a hanging light fixture are Jerry, Wade, and Stan Grossman, surrounded by the remnants of coffee cups and a partially eaten cinnamon filbert ring on the table. At the same time, Marge is stationed at the reception desk, where the clerk types into a computer console, and she speaks into a public phone. A brown Ciera car makes its way lazily, executing S-curves around the few snow-covered vehicles parked on the roof of the lot, comes to a halt beside one car, and Carl emerges, quickly surveying the lot before kneeling in the snow at the rear of the parked car to begin the task of unscrewing its license plate. Carl pulls up to the attendant and hands him his ticket, and the attendant, staring blankly with a puzzled expression, remains silent as he examines it, while Carl, glancing around, begins to search for cash, peeling off single dollar bills one by one. Confused, he looks around before raising his voice above the din of the shop to ask a passing mechanic, who points in response while Jerry observes, stares, and swallows uneasily. Marge and Shep are positioned across from each other at the opposite end of the floor in a dingy and cluttered glassed-in cubicle, engaged in silent conversation, with Shep remaining speechless as he stares directly at her. Jerry, pacing anxiously behind his desk, is taken aback when Marge appears in the doorway unexpectedly. Marge then plops herself down into the chair across from him, and Jerry stares at her, his mouth agape in surprise. As Marge stands up to leave, Jerry looks vacantly down at the papers scattered across the desk before him. Marge steps into the bar, casting her gaze around the dimly lit space—a rather nondescript meeting place favored by business people. Amidst the patrons is a bald, slightly paunchy man, approximately Marge's age, who is rising from a booth situated midway back in the establishment.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Effortlessly, she slides the plain brown paper sack across the smooth surface of the table toward him. Without the slightest hesitation, he leans forward and peers inside, discovering that the bottom is completely brimming with fat, wriggling earthworms. Meanwhile, Marge's car stands out conspicuously, parked in an otherwise barren lot. She is seen conversing with two youthful women situated at one end of an elevated dance platform within the deserted club, which is not yet ready to welcome patrons for business. With the final, resounding bang, the scene dramatically transitions to an extreme close-up of an insect diligently dragging a worm. As the camera slowly pulls back, it becomes apparent that we are, in fact, within the cozy, warmly lit confines of Marge's home, where Marge and Norm find themselves comfortably nestled in bed, watching television together. After a prolonged moment of silence, broken only by the faint sounds emanating from the TV, Marge softly murmurs while keeping her eyes lovingly fixed on the glowing screen. In the gentle darkness, Marge tentatively gropes around, and he sits, retrieving his phone with a thoughtful expression. Jerry, meanwhile, sits in a state of bewilderment, angrily snatches up the phone, and then turns his attention back to his awaiting meal. Gary hands Marge a flimsy document, which she calmly accepts with one hand, examining it intently while keeping her other hand suspended with a forkful of food poised mid-air. Norm, who has remained steadily focused on his meal, glances over at Marge with mild curiosity, taking a moment to pause and observe her intently as he finishes chewing, subsequently swallows before he finally speaks. They are seated around the kitchen table under the harsh glare of a bright hanging light fixture. Jerry, Wade, and Stan Grossman are surrounded by the remnants of empty coffee cups and a partially eaten cinnamon filbert ring on the table. Simultaneously, Marge is stationed at the reception desk, where the clerk diligently types into a computer console, and she speaks into a public phone. A brown Ciera car makes its way lazily across the lot, executing careful S-curves around the few snow-covered vehicles parked on the roof. It comes to a halt beside one of the cars, and Carl emerges, quickly surveying the lot with keen eyes before kneeling in the snow at the rear of the parked car to begin the meticulous task of unscrewing its license plate. Carl then pulls up to the attendant's booth and hands him his ticket. The attendant, staring blankly with a puzzled expression, remains silent as he examines it, while Carl, glancing around nervously, begins to search for cash, peeling off single dollar bills one by one. Confused, he looks around before raising his voice above the persistent din of the shop to ask a passing mechanic, who, in response, points in the direction while Jerry observes, stares, and swallows uneasily. Marge and Shep are positioned directly across from each other at the opposite end of the floor in a dingy, cluttered, glassed-in cubicle. They are engaged in a silent conversation, with Shep remaining utterly speechless as he stares directly at her. Jerry, pacing anxiously behind his desk, is utterly taken aback when Marge appears unexpectedly in the doorway. Marge then plops herself resolutely down into the chair that is positioned across from him, and Jerry stares at her, his mouth hanging open in sheer surprise. As Marge stands up to leave the room, Jerry looks vacantly down at the scattered papers spread across the desk before him. Marge steps into the bar, casting her gaze around the dimly lit space—a rather nondescript meeting place favored by many business people. Among the numerous patrons is a bald, slightly paunchy man, approximately Marge's age, who rises slowly from a booth situated midway back within the establishment.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: She slides the paper sack across the surface toward him, its rough texture gliding against the tabletop, prompting him to reach out and grasp it cautiously. As his fingers curl around the edge and he tilts it toward himself, his eyes peer inside to discover the sack's contents: the bottom teeming with plump, wriggling earthworms. Meanwhile, in an otherwise empty lot, Marge's prowler sits idly parked, while she herself is perched on one end of an elevated dance platform. She engages in conversation with two young women in the deserted club, which has yet to welcome patrons, as the atmosphere remains quiet and still. In a sudden, dramatic shift, the scene transitions with a final loud bang to an extreme close-up view of an insect heaving a worm. The camera then pulls back, unveiling the setting of Marge’s house, where she and Norm lie comfortably in bed, their eyes fixed on the flickering television screen. After an extended silence, punctuated only by the low hum of the TV, Marge remains focused on the set as she softly murmurs. In the darkness, Marge reaches out, her hand searching aimlessly, as another character, seated nearby, picks up his phone while Jerry, driven by his own emotions, angrily snatches it up before returning to his meal. As the scene unfolds, Gary extends a flimsy document toward her, which Marge accepts with one hand, her eyes glancing over it as the other hand remains suspended with a forkful of food. Norm, who has been consistently eating without pause, shifts his gaze toward Marge with mild curiosity, his eyes lingering for a moment as he completes his chewing, then swallows before speaking. In a differently lit environment, Jerry, Wade, and Stan Grossman are gathered around a kitchen table, the harsh light from an overhead fixture casting stark shadows as they sit amidst the remnants of coffee and a cinnamon filbert ring on the table. At the reception desk, Marge waits as the clerk types into a computer console, all while she manages a conversation on a public phone. The brown Ciera makes its entrance, lazily maneuvering in S-curves around few snow-dusted cars scattered on the lot's rooftop before halting beside a parked car. Carl steps out, conducts a quick survey of the lot, then crouches in the snow at the car's rear and begins the laborious task of unscrewing the license plate. The scene changes as Carl pulls up to the exit, handing his ticket to the attendant, who takes it with a perplexed frown, his silence filled with confusion, while Carl glances back and busies himself with retrieving money, peeling off single dollar bills. In a state of bewilderment, Carl scans his surroundings, raises his voice to inquire of a nearby mechanic over the bustling shop noises, and follows the mechanic's pointed direction. In another setting, Marge and Shep stand facing one another, separated by the glass and clutter of a grimy cubicle, where the silence between them stretches as Shep remains wordless, maintaining his unwavering gaze on her. Elsewhere, Jerry paces anxiously behind his desk, his steps halted as Marge appears at the door and proceeds to drop into the chair opposite him, capturing Jerry's stare as his mouth falls open in surprise. As Marge rises to leave, Jerry's gaze drifts down to the papers on his desk, his expression blank and uncomprehending. Entering yet another venue, Marge surveys the bar, its ambiance subdued and nondescript, serving as a meeting spot for businesspeople. Her attention is drawn to a bald, slightly overweight man of similar age to her, who rises deliberately from a booth located halfway back.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: She slides the paper sack to him, revealing it full of earthworms. Meanwhile, Marge is parked in an empty lot, conversing with two young women on a dance platform in a closed club. An extreme close-up of an insect dragging a worm transitions to Marge and Norm watching TV in their bedroom. Marge murmurs while watching, then gropes in the dark as Norm looks at her with mild interest before speaking. Jerry, Wade, and Stan Grossman sit at a kitchen table under harsh lighting, surrounded by coffee remnants and a cinnamon filbert ring. Marge uses a public phone at a reception desk while the clerk types. In the snowy parking lot, Carl drives the brown Ciera in lazy S-curves, kneels to unscrew a license plate, hands his ticket to the attendant, and pays with dollar bills. Confused, Jerry consults a mechanic over the shop noise. Marge and Shep silently interact in a cluttered glass cubicle. Jerry paces, worried, as Marge enters and sits opposite him, while Jerry stares blankly. As Marge rises, Jerry gazes at the papers on his desk. Later, Marge scans a low-lit business bar and notices a bald, paunching man about her age rising from a booth.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: She slides the paper sack toward him, and he looks inside to find the bottom full of fat, crawling earthworms, which are commonly used as bait for fishing due to their wriggling motion that attracts fish. Marge's prowler, a vintage vehicle known for its distinct design and rarity, is parked in an otherwise empty lot, and she sits talking with two young women at one end of an elevated dance platform in the deserted club not yet open for business, which is a local hotspot on weekends. With one last bang, we cut to an extreme close-up of an insect lugging a worm, a common occurrence in nature where insects such as ants carry larger prey back to their colonies, and a pull back from the screen reveals that we are in Marge's house, which is decorated with an eclectic mix of vintage furniture and family photographs, where Marge and Norm are watching television in bed. After a long beat, with silence except for the TV, Marge murmurs while still looking at the set, a typical late-night scene in their household. Marge gropes in the dark, reaching for her glasses often misplaced, and he sits in and picks up his phone, a new model with a glossy finish, while Jerry sits dumbly and angrily snatches it up, then goes back to his food which has gone cold. Gary hands her a flimsy report printout, and Marge takes it with one hand and looks, her other hand frozen with a forkful of food. Norm, who has been eating steadily throughout, looks over at Marge with mild interest, stares for a beat as he finishes chewing, then swallows and speaks with his usual slow drawl. Jerry, Wade, and Stan Grossman, a trio frequently seen together discussing business, sit around the kitchen table, harshly toplit by a hanging fixture, with the remains of coffee and a cinnamon filbert ring, a regional pastry delicacy, present on the table. Marge is at the reception desk in a bustling police station while the clerk types into a computer console, an old model that often crashes, and she is on a public phone. The brown Ciera enters and drives lazy S-curves around the few snow-covered cars parked on the roof of the lot at the local shopping mall, stops by one car, and Carl emerges, quickly scans the lot, then kneels in the snow at the back of the parked car and starts unscrewing its license plate, a common tactic for car thieves. Carl pulls up and hands the attendant his ticket, and the attendant frowns uncomprehendingly at the ticket, still puzzled, saying nothing as Carl glances back and starts digging for money, peeling off one dollar bills, which are crumpled and worn. Bewildered, he looks about, then asks a mechanic passing by, whose uniform is stained with oil, his voice raised over the din of the shop, and the mechanic points while Jerry looks, stares, and swallows. Marge and Shep face each other at the other end of the floor in a grimy and cluttered glassed-in cubicle, filled with stacks of old paperwork, silently talk, while Shep says nothing and stares at her. Jerry is worriedly pacing behind his desk when Marge has stuck in the door, then Marge plops into the chair opposite him, and Jerry stares at her, his mouth open, his mind racing to find words. As Marge rises, Jerry looks blankly down at the papers on the desk in front of him, a pile of documents he has yet to sort. Marge enters and looks around the bar, a rather characterless, lowlit meeting place for business people, and it is a bald, paunching man of about Marge's age, whose tailored suit indicates some level of corporate success, rising from a booth halfway back.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption

The brown sedan enters and drives lazy loops around the few snow-covered vans parked on the roof of the garage, stops by one van, and Carl emerges, quickly scans the garage, then kneels in the snow at the back of the parked van and starts unscrewing its hubcap. Carl pulls up and hands the attendant his receipt, and the attendant frowns uncomprehendingly at the receipt, still puzzled, saying nothing as Carl glances back and starts digging for coins, peeling off one dollar bills. Bewildered, he looks about, then asks a welder passing by, his voice raised over the din of the yard, and the welder points while Jerry looks, stares, and swallows. test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: She tosses the paper sack toward him, and he peers inside to find the bottom filled with fat, crawling earthworms. Marge's prowler is idling in an otherwise empty lot, and she lounges chatting with two young women at one end of an elevated dance platform in the deserted club not yet open for business. With one last thud, we pan to an extreme close-up of an insect dragging a worm, and a push forward from the screen reveals that we are in Marge's house, where Marge and Norm are reading magazines in bed. After a prolonged beat, with silence except for the TV, Marge whispers while still watching the set. Marge fumbles in the dark, and he reclines in and checks his phone, while Jerry sits apathetically and suddenly flings it up, then returns to his food. Gary delivers her a flimsy, and Marge grabs it with one hand and glances, her other hand paused with a forkful of food. Norm, who has been munching steadily throughout, peers over at Marge with mild curiosity, observes for a beat as he finishes munching, then swallows and comments. Jerry, Wade, and Stan Grossman lounge around the kitchen table, dimly lit by a hanging fixture, with the remnants of coffee and a cinnamon filbert ring lingering on the table. Marge is at the reception desk while the clerk glances at a computer console, and she leans on a public phone. The brown Ciera arrives and maneuvers lazy S-curves around the few snow-covered cars parked on the roof of the lot, halts by one car, and Carl appears, briefly surveys the lot, then bends down in the snow at the back of the parked car and begins tapping on its license plate. Carl strolls up and hands the attendant his ticket, and the attendant squints uncomprehendingly at the ticket, still puzzled, saying nothing as Carl glances back and starts digging for money, peeling off one dollar bills. Bewildered, he glances around, then asks a mechanic passing by, his voice raised over the din of the shop, and the mechanic gestures while Jerry glances, observes, and gulps. Marge and Shep confront each other at the other end of the floor in a grimy and cluttered glassed-in cubicle, silently converse, while Shep remains silent and gazes at her. Jerry is nervously pacing behind his desk when Marge has appeared in the door, then Marge plops into the chair opposite him, and Jerry glares at her, his mouth open. As Marge gets up, Jerry gazes blankly down at the papers on the desk in front of him. Marge strolls in and surveys the bar, a rather nondescript, lowlit meeting place for business people, and it is a bald, paunching man of about Marge's age, stepping out from a booth halfway back.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption

Betty's scooter is parked in an otherwise vacant meadow, and she sits chatting with two young sailors at one end of an elevated lecture podium in the empty library not yet open for attendees. With one final clink, we cut to an extreme close-up of a butterfly dragging a caterpillar, and a pull back from the stage reveals that we are in Betty's café, where Betty and Tom are watching a concert in bed. After a long pause, with silence except for the music, Betty whispers while still looking at the screen. Betty fumbles in the dark, and he sits in and grabs his lamp, while Milton sits quietly and irritably grabs it up, then goes back to his book. Hugh hands her a booklet, and Betty takes it with one elbow and looks, her other elbow frozen with a spoonful of ice cream. Tom, who has been snacking steadily throughout, glances over at Betty with mild curiosity, stares for a moment as he finishes chewing, then gulps and speaks. Dave pulls up and hands the cashier his leaf, and the cashier frowns uncomprehendingly at the leaf, still puzzled, saying nothing as Dave glances back and starts rummaging for coins, peeling off one nickel pieces. Confused, he looks about, then asks a gardener passing by, his voice raised over the din of the field, and the gardener points while Milton looks, gazes, and gulps. As Betty rises, Milton looks blankly down at the letters on the window in front of him. The red sedan enters and maneuvers lazy loops around the few snow-dusted vehicles parked on the roof of the building, halts by one vehicle, and Mike steps out, quickly surveys the area, then bends in the snow at the back of the parked vehicle and starts removing its hubcap. test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: She drags the plastic pouch toward him, and he peeks inside to find the bottom full of sleek, slithering eels. Marge's bicycle is parked in an otherwise empty garage, and she sits chatting with two young women at one end of a towering diving platform in the abandoned gym not yet open for practice. With one last pop, we shift to an extreme close-up of a beetle dragging a string, and a zoom out from the picture reveals that we are in Marge's cabin, where Marge and Norm are watching a movie in bed. After a long pause, with silence except for the audio, Marge whispers while still staring at the screen. Marge fumbles in the dim light, and he reclines in and picks up his remote, while Jerry sits blankly and quickly grabs it, then goes back to his puzzle. Gary shows her a pamphlet, and Marge grasps it with one hand and examines, her other hand motionless with a spoonful of ice cream. Norm, who has been nibbling steadily throughout, glances over at Marge with mild curiosity, gazes for a moment as he finishes munching, then gulps and comments. Jerry, Wade, and Stan Grossman sit around the dining table, dimly illuminated by a shaded lamp, with the remains of tea and a pecan pastry ring present on the table. Marge is at the inquiry desk while the clerk writes into a ledger book, and she is on a cellular phone. The blue sedan enters and maneuvers lazy loops around the few rain-soaked bicycles parked on the roof of the garage, stops by one bicycle, and Carl springs out, briskly observes the area, then crouches in the rain at the back of the parked bike and starts detaching its bell. Carl drives up and hands the supervisor his pass, and the supervisor frowns confusedly at the pass, still baffled, saying nothing as Carl glances back and starts searching for coins, peeling off four quarters. Disoriented, he scans the area, then asks a technician passing by, his voice raised over the racket of the warehouse, and the technician gestures while Jerry gazes, blinks, and nods. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: He shoves the cardboard box toward her, and she peers inside to find the top brimming with shiny, wriggling ribbons. Larry's wagon is stationed in a crowded garden, and he chats with three elderly men at one corner of a towering rock structure in the bustling park already open for festivities. With a final thud, we cut to a distant close-up of a bird hauling a string, and a zoom out from the wall reveals that we are in Larry's cabin, where Larry and Peg are listening to the radio on the porch. After a brief pause, with noise except for the stereo, Larry whispers while still gazing at the speakers. Larry fumbles in the light, and she reclines in and picks up her camera, while Tina reclines happily and swiftly grabs it up, then returns to her drink. Tony hands him a feather, and Larry grasps it with two fingers and examines, his other hand frozen with a spoonful of gravy. Peg, who has been sipping continually throughout, glances over at Larry with slight curiosity, gawks for a pause as she finishes swallowing, then gulps and remarks. Tina, Bill, and Ron Grossman lounge around the dining room counter, lightly illuminated by a floor lamp, with the remnants of tea and an apple pastry resting on the counter. Larry is at the mobile booth while the agent scribbles into a ledger booklet, and he is on a private radio. The green Coupe enters and maneuvers lazy Z-curves among the numerous rain-drenched trucks stationed on the edge of the field, halts near one truck, and Sam appears, leisurely surveys the field, then bends in the rain at the side of the parked truck and begins loosening its tire valve. Sam stands up and offers the guard her badge, and the guard grimaces confusedly at the badge, still perplexed, saying nothing as Sam peers back and begins searching for change, unrolling two euro coins. Astonished, she glances around, then shouts to a chef strolling by, her voice amplified over the clatter of the café, and the chef nods while Tina peers, gawks, and chews. Larry and Tina confront one another at the opposite corner of the ceiling in a tidy and organized curtained-off alcove, noiselessly converse, while Tina utters nothing and peers at him. Tina is nervously pacing alongside her cot when Larry is propped against the window, then Larry settles into the hammock beside her, and Tina gawks at him, her jaw agape. As Larry stands, Tina gazes vacantly upward at the fixtures on the wall above her. Larry exits and glances around the lounge, a rather nondescriptive, brightly lit resting area for travelers, and it is a curly, slender woman of roughly Larry's age, emerging from a chair near the entrance.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: A paper sack filled with earthworms slides toward him. Marge is at a club, talking with two women before the club opens. At home, she and Norm watch TV in bed after a close-up of an insect lugging a worm. Marge gropes in the dark, while Jerry angrily picks up his phone. Gary hands Marge a flimsy, and she takes it while eating. Norm watches Marge with interest. Jerry, Wade, and Stan Grossman sit around a kitchen table with coffee remains. Marge uses a public phone at a reception desk. A brown Ciera, driven by Carl, stops in a snowy lot, and Carl unscrews a license plate. Carl fumbles for money, handing the attendant dollar bills, confusedly asking a mechanic for help. Marge and Shep confront each other in a cluttered cubicle. Jerry paces in his office as Marge enters and sits, prompting Jerry to stare. Marge visits a bar, a dull business meeting place, where a man rises from a booth to meet her.

test_cases.name: Rotate Half Paragraph
test_cases.description: The brown Ciera enters and drives lazy Scurves around the few snowcovered cars parked on the roof of the lot stops by one car and Carl emerges quickly scans the lot then kneels in the snow at the back of the parked car and starts unscrewing its license plate Carl pulls up and hands the attendant his ticket and the attendant frowns uncomprehendingly at the ticket still puzzled saying nothing as Carl glances back and starts digging for money peeling off one dollar bills Bewildered he looks about then asks a mechanic passing by his voice raised over the din of the shop and the mechanic points while Jerry looks stares and swallows Marge and Shep face each other at the other end of the floor in a grimy and cluttered glassedin cubicle silently talk while Shep says nothing and stares at her Jerry is worriedly pacing behind his desk when Marge has stuck in the door then Marge plops into the chair opposite him and Jerry stares at her his mouth open As Marge rises Jerry looks blankly down at the papers on the desk in front of him Marge enters and looks around the bar a rather characterless lowlit meeting place for business people and it is a bald paunching man of about Marge's age rising from a booth halfway back She slides the paper sack toward him and he looks inside to find the bottom full of fat crawling earthworms Marge's prowler is parked in an otherwise empty lot and she sits talking with two young women at one end of an elevated dance platform in the deserted club not yet open for business With one last bang we cut to an extreme closeup of an insect lugging a worm and a pull back from the screen reveals that we are in Marge's house where Marge and Norm are watching television in bed After a long beat with silence except for the TV Marge murmurs while still looking at the set Marge gropes in the dark and he sits in and picks up his phone while Jerry sits dumbly and angrily snatches it up then goes back to his food Gary hands her a flimsy and Marge takes it with one hand and looks her other hand frozen with a forkful of food Norm who has been eating steadily throughout looks over at Marge with mild interest stares for a beat as he finishes chewing then swallows and speaks Jerry Wade and Stan Grossman sit around the kitchen table harshly toplit by a hanging fixture with the remains of coffee and a cinnamon filbert ring present on the table Marge is at the reception desk while the clerk types into a computer console and she is on a public phone
